journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Impact response of sandwich composites with nano-enhanced epoxy resin

contrib-group.aff: 1Depart. of Electromechanical Engineering, University of Beira Interior, Covilhã, Portugal
2CEMUC, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal
3GTG/CTA Ltd, 1 Well Holme Mead, New Farnley, Leeds, W/Yorkshire LS12 5RF, England

author-notes.corresp: PNB Reis, University of Beira Interior, Rua Marquês de Ávila e Bolama, Covilhã, 6200-001, Portugal. Email: preis@ubi.pt

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Present work intends to study the improvement of impact performance on sandwich composites by the addition of nanoclays. For this purpose, nanoclays Cloisite 30B were previously subjected to a silane treatment in order to improve their dispersion and interface adhesion. Different incident impact energy levels were used and, for both sandwiches, the maximum load, displacement or elastic recuperation shows to be very dependent of the impact energy. Mathematical relationships are proposed to estimate the maximum impact force and displacement, based on the total impact energy and impact bending stiffness. Finally, sandwiches enhanced by nanoclays presented higher maximum impact loads, lower displacements, the best performance in terms of elastic recuperation and maximum residual flexural strength.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Structural sandwich composites have been widely used in many engineering applications, such as: aircrafts, ship hulls, wind turbine blades, offshore oil platforms, bridge decks as consequence of their superior structural capacity in carrying transverse loads, superior bending stiffness, low weight, excellent thermal insulation and acoustic damping.1

These materials are composed by thin skins covering a low-density core. The skins are made of metal alloy sheet or fibre-reinforced polymer laminates in order to promote high in-plane mechanical properties (carry the transverse load or bending moment). On the other hand, the core takes care of separating and fixing the skin, carrying the transverse shear load and providing other structural or functional duties such as impact tolerance. For this purpose, a large variety of low-density materials are used in the core, being the most common: metallic honeycomb, polymer foam, syntactic foam, Nomex and balsa wood. According to Vural and Ravichandran,2 balsa wood, as a naturally occurring porous biocomposite, offers salient mechanical and physical properties. As its cellular/porous microstructure allows the application of large deformations, fine composite nano-architecture of wood cell material increases its specific strength and stiffness, giving rise to a high specific energy dissipation capacity. The density of balsa wood can vary by an order of magnitude with the age and habitat of the tree. It covers densities from 40 to 380 kg/m3 making one of the lightest woods available.3

However, such as conventional polymer matrix composites, these materials are very susceptive to the impact loads that occur during the operational or maintenance activities. Abrate,4 for example, showed that modest impact energies are capable of generating a wide range of damage including core buckling and cracking, fibre breakage and skin-core debonding. A traditional way to improve the mechanical properties is the incorporation of filler materials.5 Nanoparticles, for example, have been widely studied and applied in numerous engineering areas due to its unique surface effect, increased chemical activity and particular physical properties.6,7 For this contributes the larger surface/interface area per unit volume and, consequently, the chemical and physical interactions increasing with the matrix. Clay reinforcements, for example, have been shown to be effective nano-reinforcements in neat polymeric structures.8–16

In terms of low velocity impact strength, for example, Hosur et al.17 showed that the infusion of nanoclays in the system reduces the impact damage though the impact response in terms of the peak load remained mostly unaltered. Small damages observed were consequence of the higher stiffness and resistance to damage progression of the nanophased laminates. Smaller damage area, higher residual strength and higher threshold energy level was also obtained in CFRPs containing nanoclays by Iqbal et al.18 According to these authors, 3 wt% clay was shown to be an optimal content for the highest damage resistance. Studies performed by Avila et al.19 shows that the energy absorption of fibre glass/epoxy laminates increased by 48% with dispersion of 5 wt% of nanoclays. Reis et al.20 studied the impact behaviour as well as damage tolerance of Kevlar/filled epoxy matrix. In order to improve the impact response of these laminates, two different fillers, cork powder and nanoclays Cloisite 30B, were compared. For better dispersion and interface adhesion, matrix/clay nanoclays were previously subjected to a silane treatment appropriate to the epoxy resin. Nanoclays promoted higher maximum impact loads, lower displacements, the best performance in terms of elastic recuperation and the maximum residual tensile strength. The ideal amount of nanoclays to obtain the best impact performance on Kevlar/epoxy composites was studied by Reis et al.21 Epoxy resin enhanced by 6 wt% of nanoclays presented the best performance in terms of elastic recuperation and penetration threshold. The opposite tendency was observed for the displacement at peak load. However, marginal benefits can be found when compared the results obtained for laminates filled by 3% and 6% of nanoclays.

In terms of sandwich composites, Hosur et al.22,23 showed that these materials with nanophased foam sustained higher loads and had lower damage areas as compared with neat sandwiches. Avila et al.24 reported benefits in terms of energy absorption and failure modes with the nanoclays fillers on fibre glass/nano-modified epoxy face sheets and polystyrene foams. Other important aspect supported by Li et al.,25 for sandwich composites submitted to low velocity impact loads, is the occurrence of impact weave propagation between materials (face sheets and core). However, Avila et al.26 demonstrated that nano-modified laminated composites had their natural frequencies altered by nano-structures formed inside the laminate.

Therefore, the aim of this work is to study the benefits of resins nano-enhanced on the impact response of sandwich composites made by fibre glass/epoxy skins and balsa wood core. The epoxy resin was enhanced by nanoclays with special treatment to improve their dispersion and interface adhesion. The results of the present paper are discussed in terms of load-time, load-displacement, energy-time diagrams and residual flexural strength.

sec.title: Material and experimental procedure
sec.p: The sandwich composite specimens were fabricated using skins of glass fibre/epoxy resin and core of balsa wood with 6 mm of thickness. The facesheets are manufactured with six-ply laminates, all in the same direction, of woven bi-directional glass-fibre 1195-1000 (195 g/m2) and a green epoxy resin, SR Greenpoxy 55 and SD Glass One hardener supplied by Sicomin, were prepared by hand lay-up. Greenpoxy 55 is an epoxy system with a single hardener, where 55% of the molecular structure is of plant origin. The fictitious molecule contains 11 carbons, 6 being from biomass origin. It thus contains 55% of “green” carbon. The hardener follows the same logic. The main mechanical properties on pure cast resin are modulus of elasticity (tension) around 2.1 GPa, resistance at break around 42 MPa and Tg = 64 ℃. The overall dimensions of the plates were 500 × 100 × 8 mm3. The system was placed inside a vacuum bag and a load of 2.5 kN was applied during 24 hours in order to maintain a constant fibre volume fraction and uniform laminate thickness. With the same manufacturing process was produced composite laminates with filled epoxy matrix by organoclays Cloisite 30B. In order to improve the dispersion and interface adhesion matrix/clay, nanoclays were previously subjected to a special treatment appropriate to the epoxy resin. More details about the treatment and the dispersion/exfoliation on the epoxy matrix can be found in Ref. [20]. The nanoclays content employed was 3 wt% of the epoxy resin-hardener mixture.

The samples used in the experiments were cut from those thin plates to square specimens with 100 mm side and 8 mm thickness (100 × 100 × 8 mm3). Low-velocity impact tests were performed using a drop weight-testing machine IMATEK-IM10. More details of the impact machine can be found in Ref. [27]. Impactor diameter of 12 mm with masses of 2.925 kg was used. The tests were performed on square section samples of 75 × 75 mm and the impactor stroke at the centre of the samples obtained by centrally supporting the 100 × 100 mm specimens. The impact energies used in the tests were 4, 8, 12, 16, 20 24, 28, 32 and 36 J. These energies were previously selected in order to enable the measuring of the damage area, but without promoting full perforation of the specimens. For each condition, five specimens were tested at room temperature.

After impact tests, the specimens were submitted to three-point bending (3PB) tests. The specimens were tested with a span of 60 mm using a Shimadzu AG-10 universal testing machine equipped with a 5 kN load cell and TRAPEZIUM software at a displacement rate of 5 mm/min.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Impact tests were carried out for different impact energies and materials. Figures 1 and 2 show the force-time and force-displacement curves for sandwiches with pure epoxy resin and epoxy filled by nanoclays. These diagrams represent a typical behaviour occurred for all specimens and agree with the bibliography.18,20,21,28,29 The curves contain oscillations that, according Schoeppner and Abrate,30 result from the elastic wave and are created by the vibrations of the samples. It depends on the stiffness and the mass of the specimen and impactor being excited by the rapid variation of the cinematic magnitudes at the collision moment.31 Figure 1.
Typical diagrams load versus time for sandwiches with: (a) epoxy resin; (b) epoxy filled by nanoclays.
Figure 2.
Typical diagrams load versus displacement for sandwiches with: (a) epoxy resin; (b) epoxy filled by nanoclays.

In detail, it is possible to observe that the force increases up to a maximum value (Pmax) followed by a drop after the peak load. This is evident for control samples tested between 4 and 24 J and for specimens with resin filled by nanoclays tested between 4 and 28 J. The impact energy was not high enough to infiltrate full penetration, because the impactor sticks into specimens and rebound always. However, for impact energies higher than 28 J and 32 J (respectively for control samples and for specimens with nano-enhanced resin), after Pmax the force decrease and remain constant while the time increases. This untypical curve, compared with the others, correlates with the appearance of major damage, but still with a non-perforating impact event.

On the other hand, according to the figures, the value of Pmax is very dependent on the impact energy. Some authors found that the maximum load increases with increasing impact energy.18,20,21 and similar tendency was observed in this work, for both materials, as shown in Figure 3. Increases, between 4 and 36 J, were observed around 182.2% and 161.7% for, respectively, control samples and specimens with epoxy filled by nanoclays. However, the addition of nanoclays promoted major maximum impact loads with values, relatively to the control samples, around 24.3% higher for 4 J and 15.2% for 36 J. These results agree with the studies developed by Reis et al.20 where, for example, the addition of clays promoted maximum loads around 16.1% highest than occurred in Kevlar with pure epoxy resin. Hosur et al.17 found that the maximum load increases almost linearly with increasing impact energy, but in present study this phenomenon does not occur as consequence of the balsa core properties. For Gustin et al.,32 the differences observed in maximum forces results in the different failure modes, because each sample type has different tensile and shear properties. Figure 3.
Evolution of the maximum load with the impact energy.

Other evidence presented in Figure 3 is the fact that the peak load increases until 28 J for control samples and 32 J for specimens with nano-enhanced resin but, after this value, the energy does not show to affect significantly the maximum load. In fact, after major damages, the maximum load, apparently, increases linearly with increasing impact energy. Similar tendency was found by Found and Howard,33 which proposed an estimation of the maximum impact force based on the following equation: (1)Fmax=2·U·k where U is the total impact energy and k is the flexural stiffness of the laminates. However, equation (1) does not fit the experimental data reasonably. Therefore, the flexural stiffness was replaced by the impact bending stiffness. According to David-West et al.,34 impact bending stiffness has been known as an important property in assessing the damage resistance of a composite. In this context, a new relationship is proposed based on the following mathematical equation: (2)Fmax=c·U·kibs where U is the total impact energy, kibs is the impact bending stiffness and c a constant that is dependent on the material. The impact bending stiffness was obtained by the slope of the ascending section of the load-displacement plot according to David-West et al.34 In this case, the new equation fits very well the experimental data for the values presented in Table 1. Table 1.
Impact bending stiffness and constant values.
Sandwich (with) Impact bending stiffness Constant c Constant d
Average value (kN/m) Stand Dev (kN/m)
Epoxy resin 352.2 43.2 1.6 2.4
Resin filled by nanoclays 527.2 33.6 1.3 2.3

The average impact time was also measured and it is presented in Figure 4. In all cases, the maximum time of contact, between impactor and samples, occurred for control laminates with values around 23.5% higher, for impact energy of 4 J, and 14% higher, for 36 J, relatively to the specimens with resin filled by clays. Similar tendency was observed by Reis et al.20,21 Figure 4.
Evolution of the contact time with the impact energy.

Finally, the evolution of the displacement with the impact energy is presented in Figure 5 where, sometime, this value should be controlled in terms of design.20 When nanoclays are added to the pure resin, the displacements decrease around 23.4% and 18.7%, respectively, for impact energies of 4 J and 36 J. However, in the energy range studied (between 4 and 36 J), the displacements increase around 216.7% and 206.2%, respectively, for sandwiches manufactured exclusively with pure epoxy resin and sandwiches with resin enhanced by clays. Figure 5.
Evolution of the maximum displacement with the impact energy.

In order to estimate the maximum displacement, a new mathematical relationship is proposed by the following equation: (3)δmax=d·Ukibs where U is the total impact energy, kibs is the impact bending stiffness and d a constant that is dependent on the material. The smooth curves shown in Figure 5 represents an estimation of the maximum displacement in function of the impact energy, determined from the equation (3), and fits very well to the experimental data for the values presented in Table 1.

Figure 6 represents typical energy versus time curves. It is possible to observe that the increase in impact energy promotes a decrease of the elastic recovery and, consequently, the damage increase. The beginning of the plateau of the curve coincides with the loss of contact between the striker and the specimen, so this energy coincides with that absorbed by the specimen.20,21,35 Figure 7 compares the elastic recuperation for each sandwich. The elastic energy was calculated as the difference between the absorbed energy and the energy at peak load.20,21 The average values represented, in percentage, show that higher energies present lower elastic recuperation and, consequently, major damages. When the fillers are added better results can be found. The sandwiches manufactured with epoxy resin filled by clays present best performance in terms of elastic recuperation. For impact energies of 6 J nanoclays improve the elastic recuperation around 20.9% while for 36 J this value increases to 45.4%. However, in the energy range studied (between 4 and 36 J), the elastic recuperation decreases around 86.8% and 84%, respectively, for sandwiches manufactured with epoxy resin and sandwiches with epoxy enhanced by nanoclays. Figure 6.
Typical diagrams energy versus time for sandwiches with: (a) epoxy resin; (b) epoxy filled by nanoclays.
Figure 7.
Evolution of the elastic recuperation with the impact energy.

Figure 8 shows some pictures of the lateral view, front and back face of the damaged sandwiches with pure resin (control samples) and with epoxy resin enhanced by nanoclays. For control samples, it is notorious that a severe damage occurs in the region of the impact point and it is characterized by big deformation in the thickness direction according to Figure 5. Samples were tested until 24 J present damages on the skin that was in contact with the impactor and are essentially delaminations (see Figure 8(a) for 4 J). The delamination size increases with increasing impact energy. Major damages occur for 28 J, as shown in Figures 1 and 2, where it is possible to observe, also, matrix cracking promoted by the impact load in both faces (front and back face) and significant damages on the balsa core. For highest energies, all these damages are more expressive according to Figure 8(a). On the other hand, for sandwiches filled by clays only the face that was in contact with the impactor presents damage. The matrix filled by clays present higher stiffness and, consequently, its ductile behaviour decreases.16,20,21 In this context, the failure occurs along the matrix cracking promoted by the impact load. Figure 8.
Pictures of the damaged sandwiches with: (a) epoxy resin; (b) epoxy filled by nanoclays.

After impact, residual flexural strength was obtained for each energy level as shown in Figure 9. It is evident that the increasing of the impact energy decreases the residual strength for all laminates and is a consequence of the damage occurred. The control laminates present the lower residual flexural strength, for all impact energies, and the higher values are obtained with epoxy enhanced by nanoclays. If the difference observed for 4 J is around 54.8%, this value decreases to 53.3% when the impact energy is 36 J. The benefit promoted by the nanoclays, in terms of residual strength, agrees with Reis et al.20,21 According to these authors, the best performance in terms of impact response obtained for the filled composites was also confirmed by the tensile residual strength which increases with filler content and the differences increase with the impact energy.21 Figure 9.
Residual flexural strength versus impact energy.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The paper studied the benefits of resins nano-enhanced on the impact response of sandwich composites made by fibre glass/epoxy skins and balsa wood core. Nanoclays Cloisite 30B, especially modified for better dispersion and interface adhesion matrix/clay, were dispersed in 3% of resin weight.

The lowest displacements and the highest elastic recuperation occur for sandwiches with resin nano-enhanced. The addition of nanoclays, for example, considering an impact energy of 36 J, promotes displacements around 23.4% lower and elastic recuperation around 45.4% higher relatively to the control samples. Based on the total impact energy and impact bending stiffness, a mathematical relationship was suggested to estimate the maximum impact force and displacement.
The best performance of the sandwiches with epoxy resin enhanced by nanoclays was also confirmed by the residual flexural strength, which increases with the introduction of the nanoclays.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The authors wish to express their thanks to the Global Trading Group/CTA Ltd. for supply of the nanoclays.
